title: Websites That Use Type Well
content:
Web typography is surely not as sophisticated as it's printed cousin (or should it be mother?), but nevertheless, [some](http://web.archive.org/web/20100711093535/http:/webtypography.net/ "The Elements of Typographic Style Applied to the Web") [web](http://web.archive.org/web/20100711093535/http:/www.markboulton.co.uk/journal/comments/five_simple_steps_to_better_typography/ "Five Simple Steps to Better Typography") [designers](http://web.archive.org/web/20100711093535/http:/24ways.org/2006/compose-to-a-vertical-rhythm "Compose to a Vertical Rhythm") have worked hard to do the best they can with what they have. So I'm curious what websites the type community thinks make the best use of type on the web. I'll start.

[A List Apart](http://web.archive.org/web/20100711093535/http:/alistapart.com/ "Visit the site and see for yourself") takes full advantage of the best of the web typefaces. Sure they're just Georgia and Verdana, but when used well as they are here, they add real sophistication to a design.

[Khoi Vinhâ€™s Subtraction](http://web.archive.org/web/20100711093535/http:/www.subtraction.com/%3Ca "See for yourself") proves that type can look great on the web if used properly. Here a single font (Arial) is leveraged to its full potential with the aid of a strong underlying grid layout.

What sites inspire you to use type better on the web?
author: Peter G.

BTW, Subtraction's CSS specifies Helvetica first, but perhaps it's not installed on your system.

Actually, Stephen, I checked Subtraction's CSS before posting and it has Arial listed first, at least at the root level:  
`html, body {font-family: arial, helvetica, sans-serif;`
Well, I'll be. That's funny. He is in love with Helvetica.

(Warning: I'm on a Mac using Safari, so what I see might not be what you'll see.)

I really like these two, [Mint](http://web.archive.org/web/20100711093535/http:/www.haveamint.com/) and [SimpleBits](http://web.archive.org/web/20100711093535/http:/www.simplebits.com/). In the latter, the use of Goudy Old Style for the ampersand (yes, it's not an image), it's simply genius.

[IconBuffet](http://web.archive.org/web/20100711093535/http:/www.iconbuffet.com/) used to be one of my favorites, when they were using Helvetica.
I'm having deja vu, wasn't there a thread just like this recently about type-driven web site? can't find it tho.
